content: The Act may be cited as the "Coral Reef Conservation Legacy Act of 2006" and includes the expansion of the Coral Reef Conservation Grants Program. Approval criteria are revised to include activities to minimize damage to coral reefs and promote community-based initiatives for coral reef protection. Section 206 is amended to focus on emergency response actions for coral reef protection. The Administrator and the Secretary of the Interior may take action to prevent damage to coral reefs from vessel impacts or other physical damage, including vessel removal and emergency restabilization. Collaboration with other government agencies is encouraged. The Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to require reports to Congress. The Administrator must submit a report every 3 years to Congress detailing activities to implement coral reef conservation strategies, including funds allocated by federal agencies and collaborative efforts with states and territories to address threats to coral reefs. The Administrator, in collaboration with various federal agencies, must report on projects and disaster response actions related to coral reefs. Additionally, an assessment of accomplishments and management effectiveness in addressing coral reef threats must be provided every 3 years to Congress. SEC. 5. FUND; GRANTS; COORDINATION; TASK FORCE. The Administrator may grant funds to support coral conservation proposals, working with local communities and agencies to protect priority reef areas. Plans must align with specific criteria, be community-driven, use watershed-based approaches, involve coordination with experts, and incorporate local resource management concepts. The Administrator may grant funds for coral conservation proposals that align with specific criteria, involve local communities, and incorporate traditional resource management concepts. Terms and conditions for grants include a substitution of '75 percent' for '50 percent' in certain cases. The Administrator will collaborate with Federal agencies, States, and territorial governments to implement strategies for coral reef protection. Multiyear cooperative agreements can be made with various entities to carry out the national coral reef action strategy. Additionally, there is a United States Coral Reef Task Force in place. The United States Coral Reef Task Force is established to lead and coordinate federal actions to preserve coral reef ecosystems. Its duties include coordinating activities for mapping, monitoring, research, conservation, and restoration of coral reefs, as well as assessing the US role in international coral reef protection. The United States Coral Reef Task Force is responsible for coordinating federal actions to preserve coral reef ecosystems and promote conservation worldwide. The Task Force is comprised of various government officials including the Secretary of Commerce, Secretary of the Interior, Administrator of the Agency of International Development, Secretary of Agriculture, Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Homeland Security, and the Attorney General. The United States Coral Reef Task Force includes government officials such as the Secretary of State, Secretary of Transportation, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and Governors or their representatives from various territories and states. The United States Coral Reef Task Force includes government officials and Governors or their representatives from territories and states. Non-voting members can be appointed from Freely Associated States. Working groups can be established as needed, with participation possible from nongovernmental organizations. The United States Coral Reef Task Force can establish working groups with participation from nongovernmental organizations, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Task Force. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 212 of the Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to authorize appropriations to the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of the Interior for fiscal years 2008 to 2010. Allocation percentages for grant programs and the Fund are specified. The Coral Reef Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to authorize appropriations for fiscal years 2008 to 2010. Funding allocations for various programs and operations are specified, including support for the United States Coral Reef Task Force and community-based planning grants. Funding is authorized for marine science laboratories and coral reef research at American Samoa Community College and University of Guam. $1,000,000 is allocated to each institution for these purposes.
